awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Robust Methods for High-Dimensional Signal Processing under Geometric Constraints
awd_abstract_narration:
Our society is witnessing a surge of data-driven reforms that positively impact our lives in many aspects, thanks to technology advances that enable novel data acquisition modalities in medical and biological imaging, social and wireless sensor networks, internet-of-things, recommendation systems and so on. However, increasingly the large volume of data is acquired in an unreliable and poorly-calibrated manner, making it difficult to translate into actionable knowledge for decision making using existing methodologies. The objective of this CAREER project is to develop a unified framework, including design of provably robust and efficient algorithms, characterization of the fundamental limits, for signal reconstruction under a variety of practical considerations such as imperfect calibrations, sensor drifts, mutual coupling, corruptions and missing data during data acquisition. The success of this project will have far-reaching impacts on many applications in sensing and imaging science. 

This CAREER project will build upon recent advances in signal processing that exploit low-dimensional geometric constraints as a prior to regularize an otherwise ill-posed inference problem. Self-calibration models are introduced where the sensor perturbation is modeled as an unknown that needs to be recovered simultaneously with the signal of interest. The transformative aspect is to recognize that the perturbation also exhibits low-dimensional geometric structures, which shall be exploited in an integrated manner with the low-dimensional geometric structure of the signal of interest to render a well-posed inference problem to enable self-calibration. The CAREER program will advance STEM education by developing tailored educational components for students at all levels, designing signal processing modules that are appropriate for dissemination to K-12 students, and involving women and underrepresented students to promote their success through outreach activities.

por.por_cntn:
Modern sensing and imaging technologies produce vast amounts of data ubiquitously at an unprecedented rate. The fundamental goal of information and signal processing is to extract, and possibly track the relevant information faithfully from these high-dimensional data for decision making with a minimal requirement of computation, storage, resources, human intervention, and so on. To deal with the curse of dimensionality, it is recognized that many real-world data exhibits some postulated low-dimensional geometric structures, including but not limited to the celebrated sparse and low-rank models, such that it can be described by a number of parameters much smaller than the ambient dimension. This has been the key premise that enables recent advances in compressed sensing, high-dimensional statistics and machine learning, where low-dimensional geometric constraints are imposed on the signal of interest to regularize an otherwise ill-posed inference problem.

However, due to cost, power, and resource limitations inpractical scenarios, it becomes increasingly common that the data is acquired using unreliable and poorly-calibrated sensing devices, introducing undesirable sensor perturbations to the acquired data that cannot be well captured by existing data acquisition models. Naive applications of existing algorithms would suffer from model mismatch between the low-dimensional geometric structure of the acquired data, and the geometric constraints enforced in the signal processing algorithms, leading to significant performance degradation. Therefore, signal processing algorithms need to be designed in a robust manner with respect to imperfections of sensor measurements in order to fully harness the power of low-dimensional geometric structures, at the same time being statistically and computationally efficient to be amenable for mining large-scale sensory data.

This CAREER program has developed novel and effective methodologies for calibration-free and outlier-resilient statistical inference algorithms by combining existing and developing new concepts in robust statistics, harmonic analysis, convex and nonconvex optimization techniques. By leveraging low-dimensional geometric constraints of signal representation and signal acquisition in an integrated manner, this CAREER program provides computationally efficient algorithms with provable performance guarantees for robust signal reconstruction using uncalibrated sensor measurements. The findings of this CAREER project has been disseminated through conferences presentations and publications, and through integration into education materials. It has far-reaching implications in a broad range of sensing and imaging applications such as sensor networks, radar and sonar, inverse scattering, optical and medical imaging, where it is greatly desirable to robustly estimate a low-dimensional signal from a limited amount of measurements that are noisy, corrupted or uncalibrated in a provably-efficient manner.
